question.title: How to get Java applications to store fonts somewhere other than ~/.java?
question.body:
On GNU/Linux, Java apps use ~/.java/ to store fonts and other look-n-feel bits.

Is there some environment variable I can set to move this to another location?

answers.body: As of now, this seems to be impossible, short of patching Java yourself. There is upstream bug report: https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8290140 and Fedora might patch it: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1154277

question_comments.body: @Chris Kudos for fixing this Question, to make it legitimate.

@BasilBourque, what makes you think this is about deployment? It looks like a question about configuring this behaviour as an end user to me. It would help if OP weighed in, but they've been silent since posting over 24 hours ago.

It appears the ~/.java/fonts directory is hard-coded, so there’s nothing you can do about it except maybe change the user.home property (which has a lot of other implications). As others have pointed out, you can set the java.util.prefs.userRoot property to prevent ~/.java/.userPrefs from being written. It appears some other directories used to be created in ~/.java but no longer are.

The user.home change might work but clarify which apps you mean. For example jshell will use ~/.java for user prefs and you can make it save .java to another location with jshell -J-Duser.home=/tmp/another. teapot418's suggestion is better, for example jshell -J-Djava.util.prefs.userRoot=otherdir
You can also try defining a java.util.prefs.userRoot.
Its unclear what apps you mean. If your app uses a path derived from user.home then you might try to see whether java -Duser.home=anotherdir changes the place of .java folder

When I use a recent Java version, I download a zip or tar.gz, extract it to some place and run it from there, without touching anything else in the system. I don’t see a reason to copy fonts or “other look-n-feel bits” from the Java installation directory to some other directory, like that .java directory. So, are we really talking about a common behavior of “Java apps” or is it a very specific application that does this?

XDG places no requirements on what applications must do or where certain kinds of files must be stored. It has some advantages, else it would not have gained any traction, but it is something that applications must opt into. For their part, dotfiles and dot-directories directly in users' home directories is a convention with much more tradition than the XDG arrangement has. I'd be amazed if .java were the only such one in your home directory. I can understand preferring the greater organization provided by XDG, but "hideous" seems hyperbolic.
